Pore/Structural Features.Structure Type: Amorphous structures composed of Al3+-alginate crosslinks and Al3+-phosphonate organic ligand complexes

Guest Molecules.Molecular Size: 0.76 Å (ionic radius, dehydrated state), 0.38 nm (hydrated radius)

Other Information.Test Conditions: Varies with reaction temperature and time (24 h or 48 h), pH 7, concentrations of 500 ppm and 1000 ppm
Other Information.Additional Info: Li+ ions are rejected in a dehydrated state due to strong repulsion from Al3+ ions coordinated within negatively charged groups. Dehydration occurs due to the synergistic effect of intertwined amorphous structure and Al3+-phosphonate organic ligand complexes.

Other Information.Test Conditions: Varies with reaction temperature and time (24 h or 48 h), pH 7, concentrations of 500 ppm and 1000 ppm
Other Information.Additional Info: Mg2+ ions remain hydrated and are effectively adsorbed due to their higher hydration energy compared to Li+ ions.

Other Information.Test Conditions: Reaction temperature 90 °C, 24 h, pH 7, initial concentration 1000 ppm
Other Information.Additional Info: Na+ ions exhibit lower adsorption capacity compared to Li+ due to repulsion from trivalent Al3+ ions.

Other Information.Test Conditions: Reaction temperature 90 °C, 24 h, pH 7, initial concentration 1000 ppm
Other Information.Additional Info: K+ ions exhibit lower adsorption capacity compared to Li+ due to repulsion from trivalent Al3+ ions.

Sieving Mechanism: Size confinement effect through dehydration for small hydration energy ions (e.g., Li+)

Experimental Validation.Method: Adsorption experiments, PXRD, FTIR, TEM, EDS, Solid-state NMR
Experimental Validation.Performance Metrics: Li+/Mg2+ selectivity varies with reaction conditions; maximum adsorption capacities: Li+ = 0.664 mmol g-1, Mg2+ = 0.323 mmol g-1 (at 80 °C, 48 h)

Other Information.Additional Info: Amorphous structures modulated by reaction temperature, intertwinement degree of alginate networks, and partial hydrolysis. The material exhibits tunable ion sieving behavior without selective porosity.
